20. Indeed, the spatter from the sponge stayed
hanging from his Horse’s mouth, just like actual foam;
thus from this angry gesture, he realized
his intention in his work. While ascribed to luck,
and not to his Art, it is the same.
In sum, one discovers here with what devotion
and fervor the ancients sought
how best to depict all details.

21. In Rome in the hall of Constantine,
that foam is depicted properly.
Protogenes, according to Pliny’s account,
could not paint the foam on a Dog
as he intended, and fared so poorly
painting weak forms that he attacked his work
with a sponge–the same as we saw above–
and it looked so fine that all were compelled to praise it.
right-middleExample of Horses’ foam, in the Constantine Battle in Belvedere.

22. For first this foam did not look natural,
says Pliny, and was quite different
from its true appearance in life; but seemed
diligently painted, for taking great pains, he wished
to show the foam flowing from the mouth.
Nealcas also painted a young man leading it,
or holding and stroking it;
there too, his sponge worked miracles.

23.Thus we might also, as appropriate, study
the foam of horses, with busy perseverance.
How something is made, with thumbs,
or a sponge, or anything else uncommon,
whatever looks good, is good; this I find worthy.
But one can well grasp that antique artists
put great effort into painting horses well,
because there was praise to be won.
right-middleWhat looks good, is good.

div.ab:
24. Apelles, the Chief painter of Antiquity,
with more other Painters of his time,
had a competition among themselves:
but he, fearing that People would
judge his work badly out of envy,
and favor the other side,
to the advantage of his rivals,
he much preferred the judgment of Animals.
right-middleIn earlier times, one worked very hard painting Horses, for there was Praise to be earned.

25. So he led real Horses to the group
of Steeds he had painted. But was there
a flaw? They walked by like muzzled Oxen,
without making any noise.
right-middleApelles coveted the judgment of Animals: Horses snorted at his painted Horses.
